urn:contentItem:54N9-J6F1-JD67-1565-00000-00No charges for killing intruder WASHINGTON2012-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:01ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 23No charges for killing intruder WASHINGTONWire importer

No charges for killing intruder WASHINGTON | No charges will be laid against a teenage mother in Oklahoma who rang emergency services on New Year's Eve and asked if it might be OK for her to gun down an intruder at her mobile home. Sarah McKinley, 18, shot and killed Justin Martin, 24, with a 12-gauge shotgun after calling police and asking in a near-whisper: "I've got two guns in my hand. Is it OK to shoot him if he comes through the door?"

Grady County sheriff's dispatcher Diane Graham replied, "I can't tell you that you can do that, but you have to do what you have to do to protect your baby." Graham then heard a gunshot over the telephone line. Police determined the mother of a three-month-old baby | whose cancer-stricken husband died on Christmas Day | had acted in self-defence. Navy SEAL shoots himself SAN DIEGO | San Diego police say a Navy SEAL is on life support after accidentally shooting himself in the head. Officer Frank Cali said officers were called to a home in Pacific Beach early on Thursday morning on a report that a man had been playing with a gun and accidentally shot himself. Cali says the man was showing guns to a woman he'd met earlier at a bar and put a pistol he believed was unloaded to his head. Cali says he then pulled the trigger. Forest fire 'lit by terrorists' SANTIAGO | Chilean President Sebastian Pinera says six people have died in the forest fire affecting the municipality of Carrahue, 700 kilometres south of Santiago, and he claimed that the outbreak of the fire itself was a terrorist act. After confirming that six firefighters were injured as they tried to extinguish the flames in Carahua, the president emphatically stated that "terrorist behaviour hides behind these deliberately caused fires".

urn:contentItem:457Y-MGG0-0197-53J8-00000-00<published>1997-09-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:36:01Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire licks the outskirts of Lost City of the Incas</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MORE than 1000 farmers and several dozen tourists were evacuated yesterday from villages around the Inca citadel of Machu Picchu in the Peruvian Andes as fire engulfed two mountains and a valley near the archaeological World Heritage site known as the Lost City of the Incas.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Peruvian authorities said the flames had not damaged the ruins and were being contained to an area more than 11/2km from what is believed to have been the Incas' most sacred ceremonial centre.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But experts feared the destruction of thousands of hectares of spectacular tropical forests around it and smoke damage to the stone ruins would damage its attraction to tourists. Machu Picchu, 480km south-east of Lima, is Peru's top tourist attraction.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Times, AP </p></bodyText></section><p>"One of the main attractions of Machu Picchu for visitors was its spectacular location among sheer cliffs and tropical forests. If these forests burn, it will clearly affect its attractiveness to tourists," said Peruvian archaeologist Federico Kauffman-Doig.</p><p> Fire broke out on mountainsides around Machu Picchu on Sunday and was put out on Monday, but dry and windy weather, coupled with peasants burning weeds in their fields, are thought to have started a new blaze yesterday.</p><p> Fires are common at this time of year, but have never come so close to the spectacular stone ruins.</p><p> "Helicopters are being used to douse the mountainsides below the citadel with water.</p><p>We will make sure the fire does not reach the ruins," said Carlos Valencia, director of the archaeological site.</p><p> No one has been reported injured and the authorities said that the fire had not affected hotels, villages or the railway that runs from nearby Cuzco to Machu Picchu.</p><p> But dozens of hitch-hikers from Israel, Germany and France who had been trekking along the main path up to the ruins were evacuated to Cuzco.</p><p> More than 1000 subsistence farmers and llama herdsmen from Aguas Calientes were also evacuated.</p><p> Firefighters are using three helicopters equipped with water tanks to fight the fire. "This is very expensive for a poor country like Peru. Each flight costs some $US13,000 ($18,060). But we have to do everything to save our most famous tourist site," said Mr Valencia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5WKY-KK81-JD34-V4GD-00000-00Koala numbers drop2019-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:01ZLexisNexisSATURDAYKoala numbers dropKyra Gillespie

80 per cent decline in nine months

Framlingham has lost 80 per cent of its koala population in just nine months as part of a management program aimed at addressing overpopulation.

The animal numbers have dwindled after 200 koalas were removed from the township and translocated to other forests in October last year.

Carried out by the state environment department, the koala management program sought to address high koala numbers, declining tree health and loss of food trees, such as Manna Gum and River Red Gum.

It included koala health checks and fertility control of female koalas to reduce breeding rates.

Department of Environment, Land Water and Planning (DELWP) statewide wildlife programs manager Vural Yazgin said 193 koalas underwent health checks and 76 females had their fertility controlled to reduce their breeding rates at the time.

He said 23 koalas with health issues were also euthanised.

"The program was necessary due to a significant increase in koala numbers at Framlingham over the last decade," he said.

A visit to the site this month revealed a significant reduction in koala numbers.

"DELWP visited the Framlingham township in November 2018 and again in July 2019 to monitor koala density and tree health," DELWP's acting regional manager of environmental compliance Mark Breguet said.

"The population of koalas is significantly reduced as a result of the active management by DELWP.

"From a recent survey, it is estimated that there is at least an 80 per cent reduction in koala numbers in the area."

He said trees affected by overfeeding were looking better.

"The trees affected by over-browsing in 2018 are markedly recovering as a result of the koala management program," Mr Breguet said.

"Trees throughout the township are generally exhibiting increased foliage growth, however some large old trees in the township and along the Hopkins River were unfortunately not able to recover.

"Residents spoken to are generally happy with the results of the management program, with many of the trees recovering and a much more sustainable koala density continuing to live in the township. "Some preferred food trees continue to exhibit reduced canopy cover or signs of defoliation, and it will be important to continue to monitor the health of the koala population and their habitat."

The tree issue is believed to be the result of koalas that were displaced and searching for new habitat following the Framlingham Forest fire in 2005-2006.

The majority were translocated to Claude Austin and Fergusson's State Forest, south of Rocklands Reservoir, west of the Grampians.

The koala population at Tower Hill has dropped to a low of 60 after 800 were removed from the wildlife reserve around 30 years ago.

"A mass relocation of more than 800 koalas from Tower Hill Wildlife Reserve occurred nearly 30 years ago to manage what was an unsustainable population," Parks Victoria ranger team leader Ben Hammond said.

"Many koalas were in poor health and they were at risk of killing their food source from over-browsing.

"For the past 20 years there's been a fertility control program to support a sustainable and healthy population of koalas and to maintain the Manna Gum habitat they need.

"Our latest count indicates there are between 60 and 80 koalas in the reserve, a population that is appropriate for the habitat available to them."

Roy Baker, site manager at the Framlingham Aboriginal Trust, said the koalas in the trust's forests were happy and healthy.

"We're on the other side of the township so we haven't had any koalas removed and it doesn't appear that we have an overpopulation," he said.

urn:contentItem:7V0X-08W1-2RR2-D1T5-00000-00Policy critics predicted 'inevitable mega-fires'2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Policy critics predicted 'inevitable mega-fires'VICTORIA'S DARKEST WEEKANDREW RULE

A GROUP of forest-fire experts has accused state Environment Minister Gavin Jennings of attempting to deceive the public - and of pre-empting a royal commission - over fuel-reduction burning.

Mr Jennings this week defended the Government over suggestions it had contributed to Australia's worst peacetime disaster by tacitly neglecting its commitment to fuel-reduction burning to appease the green lobby.

Forest Fire Victoria - a group of forestry experts and scientists, including outspoken academic David Packham - claims the Government has sidelined crucial recommendations from its own parliamentary environment and natural resources committee to curry favour with environmentalists.

The dispute flared when Mr Jennings said this week Victoria had carried out 400,000hectares of fuel-reduction burning over three years - and the proposed royal commission would back his Government's stance.

Mr Packham yesterday accused the minister of deception. "It's true they have done fuel-reduction burning on 400,000 hectares - but everyone else is talking per year and he's talking about burning that much every three years," he said. "If it's not deception, it's stupidity - and I can't believe he (Mr Jennings) is that stupid."

Fuel-reduction burning of 400,000 hectares in three years represented only 1 per cent of Victoria's bushland a year - when 10 per cent was needed to safeguard the state properly and the Government's own committee had urged an annual minimum of 5 per cent fuel-reduction burning, Mr Packham said.

Mr Packham said he was willing to risk being dismissed from his post as honorary senior research fellow at Monash University's school of geography and environmental science rather than stay silent. It is believed his criticism of bushfire management has made him unpopular in some circles at the university.

Former Victorian environment minister John Thwaites, widely seen as the architect of Victoria's relatively modest reduction-burning policy, has been appointed a professor at Monash since stepping down from Parliament.

Just seven weeks ago, Forest Fire Victoria warned that the apparent failure to act on the recommendations of the Victorian Parliamentary Environment and Natural Resources Committee last June would lead to dangerous fuel loads in Victorian bushland.

Members of Forest Fire Victoria include long-time University of Melbourne botanist (and former forester) Professor Peter Attiwill and the state's former commissioner of forests and, later, chief fire officer, Athol Hodgson.

Mr Hodgson circulated a tough critique of the Government's Living With Fire policy when it was released in mid-December, predicting it would fail and warning that the unprecedented fuel loads in the bush would trigger catastrophic fires.

The parliamentary committee had made 20 recommendations, of which the Government had adopted seven and supported 13 "in principle". "It means they did nothing," Mr Hodgson said.

In his critique, he described the Government's reaction to the committee recommendations as "a farce, conveniently ambiguous and deceptive to the point of arrogance" and paying "lip service only". His colleague, Professor Attiwill, said: "It's a Yes Minister response to avoid doing anything while at the same time appearing to act."

Professor Attiwill said that preventing controlled "ecological burning" in cool autumn weather would inevitably lead to mega-fires.

"Hot fires like that kill things," Professor Attiwill said. "If not people, then millions of animals and birds. While all the emphasis is on fire suppression, rather than on fire prevention, it will happen again and again.

"The science of fire is simple. All that's needed for a fire is a source of ignition, fuel, and the right conditions - wind and heat. And the only one of those we can control is the fuel load."

urn:contentItem:5XC0-24R1-JBF5-T3PP-00000-00Fire evacuation drill in Victoria prepares entire towns for summer bushfire season2019-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:01ZLexisNexisFire evacuation drill in Victoria prepares entire towns for summer bushfire seasonBy Emilia Terzon and staff

Hundreds of residents from three Victorian towns have been told to evacuate from their homes as part of one of the state's biggest-ever fire drills, in preparation for what could be a devastating fire season.

Around 400 people living in the Yarra Ranges towns of Powelltown, Three Bridges and Gilderoy started receiving text messages on Friday night, simulating the warnings they would receive during a real-life bushfire.

By Saturday, the mock message was more urgent: "It is strongly recommended that you evacuate now."

The small towns, about 70 kilometres east of Melbourne's centre, were warned about the drill on October 15.

The chief officer of the Country Fire Service (CFA), Steve Warrington, said the exercise was "all about making sure people are safe" and ensuring there was not a repeat of the deadly 2009 Black Saturday bushfires.

"For us, there were a number of learnings, particularly out of Black Saturday, for all of us. And for the emergency services, one of those learnings was how we as a sector ... connect with our communities," he said.

The day began with rain and hail in the area, which Mr Warrington acknowledged was "quite bizarre" on a day of preparing for fire.

Debra Abbott, the deputy emergency management commissioner at Emergency Management Victoria, said the exercise was vital before heading into what was forecast to be a hot, dry summer.

"Plan for summer, because if the fire's on your doorstep, that's too late," she said.

Bushfire season started early this year and several devastating fires have torn through Queensland and New South Wales - including a   bushfire threatening homes in northern NSW as the fire drill took place in Victoria.

"We are watching what's happening in Queensland and New South Wales, we currently have crews on the ground in New South Wales supporting them at the moment, so if that's a reflection to what's occurred, then yes [that is concerning]," Mr Warrington said.

"We live in one of the worst bushfire-prone areas in the world. Victorians know that. We've got a long, long history of significant bushfires where significant life is lost, property is lost. Every year there will be some sort of property loss.

"That's what we live in. People need to acknowledge that and be prepared for it."

Residents were told at 12:30pm that they should evacuate.

The neighbouring towns only have one road in and one road out, which emergency officials said made it very challenging for residents to leave their homes late.

"We really need the community to jump on board and undertake and participate in the exercises," Superintendent Nigel Howard from Victoria Police said.

"But more importantly, particularly those living in rural and remote areas ... have a fire plan and know what you're going to do."

Around 50 people left their homes for the evacuation centre in Powelltown.

At the nearby pub, it was business as usual, with the staff there deciding not to participate but to keep running the shop.

However, pub worker Tracy Connors said the exercise had made her think about her fire plan, given she lives on a small block near town.

"We're definitely the sort of people to evacuate," she said.

Powelltown does have a fire bunker, which was manned during the drill by Ronald Gribble from Forest Fire Management Victoria.

But he said it should only be used as a place of last resort during an emergency.

"You could fit the whole town in here if you had to but it wouldn't be comfortable," he said.

The CFA's Mr Warrington said the day was about encouraging people to come up with a plan and be prepared to leave quickly when necessary.

"You will not get someone knocking on your door," he warned.

"Plan as if the fire services, the emergency services don't exist, and if we turn up, it's a bonus."

"Some preferred food trees continue to exhibit reduced canopy cover or signs of defoliation, and it will be important to continue to monitor the health of the koala population and their habitat."

The tree issue is believed to be the result of koalas that were displaced and searching for new habitat following the Framlingham Forest fire in 2005-2006.

The majority were translocated to Claude Austin and Fergusson's State Forest, south of Rocklands Reservoir, west of the Grampians.

The koala population at Tower Hill has dropped to a low of 60 after 800 were removed from the wildlife reserve around 30 years ago.

"A mass relocation of more than 800 koalas from Tower Hill Wildlife Reserve occurred nearly 30 years ago to manage what was an unsustainable population," Parks Victoria ranger team leader Ben Hammond said.

"Many koalas were in poor health and they were at risk of killing their food source from over-browsing.

"For the past 20 years there's been a fertility control program to support a sustainable and healthy population of koalas and to maintain the Manna Gum habitat they need.

"Our latest count indicates there are between 60 and 80 koalas in the reserve, a population that is appropriate for the habitat available to them."

Roy Baker, site manager at the Framlingham Aboriginal Trust, said the koalas in the trust's forests were happy and healthy.

"We're on the other side of the township so we haven't had any koalas removed and it doesn't appear that we have an overpopulation," he said.

urn:contentItem:5XC0-24R1-JBF5-T3PG-00000-00Fire evacuation drill in Victoria prepares entire towns for summer bushfire season2019-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:01ZLexisNexisFire evacuation drill in Victoria prepares entire towns for summer bushfire seasonBy Emilia Terzon and staff

Hundreds of residents from three Victorian towns have been told to evacuate from their homes as part of one of the state's biggest-ever fire drills, in preparation for what could be a devastating fire season.

Around 400 people living in the Yarra Ranges towns of Powelltown, Three Bridges and Gilderoy started receiving text messages on Friday night, simulating the warnings they would receive during a real-life bushfire.

By Saturday, the mock message was more urgent: "It is strongly recommended that you evacuate now."

The small towns, about 70 kilometres east of Melbourne's centre, were warned about the drill on October 15.

The chief officer of the Country Fire Service (CFA), Steve Warrington, said the exercise was "all about making sure people are safe" and ensuring there was not a repeat of the deadly 2009 Black Saturday bushfires.

"For us, there were a number of learnings, particularly out of Black Saturday, for all of us. And for the emergency services, one of those learnings was how we as a sector ... connect with our communities," he said.

The day began with rain and hail in the area, which Mr Warrington acknowledged was "quite bizarre" on a day of preparing for fire.

Debra Abbott, the deputy emergency management commissioner at Emergency Management Victoria, said the exercise was vital before heading into what was forecast to be a hot, dry summer.

"Plan for summer, because if the fire's on your doorstep, that's too late," she said.

Bushfire season started early this year and several devastating fires have torn through Queensland and New South Wales - including a   bushfire threatening homes in northern NSW as the fire drill took place in Victoria.

"We are watching what's happening in Queensland and New South Wales, we currently have crews on the ground in New South Wales supporting them at the moment, so if that's a reflection to what's occurred, then yes [that is concerning]," Mr Warrington said.

"We live in one of the worst bushfire-prone areas in the world. Victorians know that. We've got a long, long history of significant bushfires where significant life is lost, property is lost. Every year there will be some sort of property loss.

"That's what we live in. People need to acknowledge that and be prepared for it."

Residents were told at 12:30pm that they should evacuate.

The neighbouring towns only have one road in and one road out, which emergency officials said made it very challenging for residents to leave their homes late.

"We really need the community to jump on board and undertake and participate in the exercises," Superintendent Nigel Howard from Victoria Police said.

"But more importantly, particularly those living in rural and remote areas ... have a fire plan and know what you're going to do."

Around 50 people left their homes for the evacuation centre in Powelltown.

At the nearby pub, it was business as usual, with the staff there deciding not to participate but to keep running the shop.

However, pub worker Tracy Connors said the exercise had made her think about her fire plan, given she lives on a small block near town.

"We're definitely the sort of people to evacuate," she said.

Powelltown does have a fire bunker, which was manned during the drill by Ronald Gribble from Forest Fire Management Victoria.

But he said it should only be used as a place of last resort during an emergency.

"You could fit the whole town in here if you had to but it wouldn't be comfortable," he said.

The CFA's Mr Warrington said the day was about encouraging people to come up with a plan and be prepared to leave quickly when necessary.

"You will not get someone knocking on your door," he warned.

"Plan as if the fire services, the emergency services don't exist, and if we turn up, it's a bonus."

urn:contentItem:5WKY-KK81-JD34-V46W-00000-00Koala numbers drop2019-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:36:01ZLexisNexisKoala numbers dropKyra Gillespie

80 per cent decline in nine months

Framlingham has lost 80 per cent of its koala population in just nine months as part of a management program aimed at addressing overpopulation.

The animal numbers have dwindled after 200 koalas were removed from the township and translocated to other forests in October last year.

Carried out by the state environment department, the koala management program sought to address high koala numbers, declining tree health and loss of food trees, such as Manna Gum and River Red Gum.

It included koala health checks and fertility control of female koalas to reduce breeding rates.

Department of Environment, Land Water and Planning (DELWP) statewide wildlife programs manager Vural Yazgin said 193 koalas underwent health checks and 76 females had their fertility controlled to reduce their breeding rates at the time.

He said 23 koalas with health issues were also euthanised.

"The program was necessary due to a significant increase in koala numbers at Framlingham over the last decade," he said.

A visit to the site this month revealed a significant reduction in koala numbers.

"DELWP visited the Framlingham township in November 2018 and again in July 2019 to monitor koala density and tree health," DELWP's acting regional manager of environmental compliance Mark Breguet said.

"The population of koalas is significantly reduced as a result of the active management by DELWP.

"From a recent survey, it is estimated that there is at least an 80 per cent reduction in koala numbers in the area."

He said trees affected by overfeeding were looking better.

"The trees affected by over-browsing in 2018 are markedly recovering as a result of the koala management program," Mr Breguet said.

"Trees throughout the township are generally exhibiting increased foliage growth, however some large old trees in the township and along the Hopkins River were unfortunately not able to recover.

"Residents spoken to are generally happy with the results of the management program, with many of the trees recovering and a much more sustainable koala density continuing to live in the township. "Some preferred food trees continue to exhibit reduced canopy cover or signs of defoliation, and it will be important to continue to monitor the health of the koala population and their habitat."

The tree issue is believed to be the result of koalas that were displaced and searching for new habitat following the Framlingham Forest fire in 2005-2006.

The majority were translocated to Claude Austin and Fergusson's State Forest, south of Rocklands Reservoir, west of the Grampians.

The koala population at Tower Hill has dropped to a low of 60 after 800 were removed from the wildlife reserve around 30 years ago.

"A mass relocation of more than 800 koalas from Tower Hill Wildlife Reserve occurred nearly 30 years ago to manage what was an unsustainable population," Parks Victoria ranger team leader Ben Hammond said.

"Many koalas were in poor health and they were at risk of killing their food source from over-browsing.

"For the past 20 years there's been a fertility control program to support a sustainable and healthy population of koalas and to maintain the Manna Gum habitat they need.

"Our latest count indicates there are between 60 and 80 koalas in the reserve, a population that is appropriate for the habitat available to them."

Roy Baker, site manager at the Framlingham Aboriginal Trust, said the koalas in the trust's forests were happy and healthy.

"We're on the other side of the township so we haven't had any koalas removed and it doesn't appear that we have an overpopulation," he said.
